comments:
20020601
selfhosting workspace
CVS decorators on (no others)
Required binary project for org.eclipse.jdt.ui except org.eclipse.debug.core, 
org.eclipse.debug.ui, org.eclipse.jdt.debug, org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests, 
org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui, org.eclipse.jdt.launching, 
org.eclipse.jdt.launching.j9 as source.

As far as I can tell org.eclipse.debug.core/doc does exist

The cause of the exception is the attempted retrieval of sync info on a folder 
that doesn't exist (although the reported says the folder in question does 
exist which is odd: related to bug 18606?). This case should probably be 
detected and not result in an exception (either by the EclipseSynchronizer or 
the CVSDecorator). As it is now, the CVSDecorator catches the exception and 
logs it. There would be no other side effects.

Did you ever delete anything before this happened?

No deletions had occurred by the user request.  Entirely new workspace.  Binary 
imported projects, add projects from repository.  Debugged.  Not entirely sure 
when the exception occurred...sorry.

Mike, please keep the heat up on this.  Enlist Tony for extra testing to 
reproduce bug if required.

What order did you use to populate your workspace (i.e. did you load the binary 
projects first and then the one from dev.eclipse.org)?

I believe in this case I added the source from dev first and then added the 
binary.  I did this at home so I can't look at the timestamps currently.

Did you load all the projects from dev.eclipse.org together or one at a time. 
Was the automatic build off?

Autobuild on
All projects from dev at once
All binary projects at once

Was there anything special about your setup (e.g. workspace on a network drive, 
etc.)

Not that I am aware of...an older Win98 box using a cable modem to access 
dev.eclipse.org (not VPN). Everything else was local.

I found this in my log today but it was after the fact as well. I did get an 
error when I tried a Replace With Tag or Version after cancelling the same 
operation previously. Do you remember if you cancelled any operations you were 
peforming?
I do not remember cancelling any operations.

I suspect that the exception reported in this bug occurred because the 
CVSDecorator was referencing information associated with an IResource at the 
same time it was being set (the exception says the user doesn't exist but the 
user says the resource always did).

In looking through the CVSDecorator isDirty code, we are inconsistant in how we 
handle exceptions. In one place (isDirty(ICVSFile) where the exception of this 
bug occured) we log the exception and set the resource dirty. In another place 
(isDirty(IResource)), we eat the exceptions and don't set the resource as 
dirty. 

I think we have two options when an exception occurs
1) remove the logging and set the resource as dirty
2) log the exceptions and set the resource as dirty
In either case, we shoudl investigate the core code involved for multi-
threading issues.

Here's another exception. It's a little different but probably related. The
symptom was a dirty indicator on (and only on) Eclipse SWT Drag and Drop
